images.caption: Figure 2:An overview of CPPO.For each rolloutùê®i\mathbf{o}_{i}, perception tokens are identified and their probability distributions are computed under three conditions: the original imageII(anchor sample:œÄŒ∏‚Äã(oi,t)\pi_{\theta}(o_{i,t})), an information-preserving perturbationI+I^{+}(positive sample:œÄŒ∏+‚Äã(oi,t)\pi_{\theta}^{+}(o_{i,t})), and an information-removing perturbationI‚àíI^{-}(negative sample:œÄŒ∏‚àí‚Äã(oi,t)\pi_{\theta}^{-}(o_{i,t})). Similaritiess‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(œÄŒ∏‚Äã(oi,t),œÄŒ∏+‚Äã(oi,t))sim\big(\pi_{\theta}(o_{i,t}),\pi_{\theta}^{+}(o_{i,t})\big)ands‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(œÄŒ∏‚Äã(oi,t),œÄŒ∏‚àí‚Äã(oi,t))sim\big(\pi_{\theta}(o_{i,t}),\pi_{\theta}^{-}(o_{i,t})\big)are computed and incorporated into the Contrastive Perception Loss (CPL), which serves as an additional perception-specific term in the RL objective. Notations are simplified for brevity.
